Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of Gene Regulatory Networks for Development of Novel Structures in Echinoderm Embryos
Award.AbstractNarration: The great diversity of animal morphology is due to genomic changes that alter the programming of development; however, the exact nature of such changes is poorly understood. For many technical reasons the genetic basis of development is extraordinarily well understood in sea urchin embryos, especially that of a cell lineage that will form the skeleton of the larva. This cell lineage is an evolutionary novelty as it is not found in the embryos of the other groups of animals related to the sea urchin (e.g. sea stars and sea cucumbers). This provides the exceptional opportunity to understand how regulatory changes have occurred during evolution to allow the development of an entirely novel morphology. All of the same (orthologous) genes, with the exception of just one, that are needed to make the sea urchin skeleton lineage are also expressed in the sea star embryo. This preliminary data demonstrates that this developmental novelty, therefore, is not due to the acquisition of new genes, but rather a change in the way in which these same genes function. This project will determine the regulatory interactions between these orthologous genes in sea star embryos in order to understand how their function has evolved in the sea urchin. Gene products will be perturbed using various molecular approaches and the effect on development and expression of other genes will be determined. A series of cross-species experiments will also be undertaken, where gene products from sea stars will be injected into the embryo of the sea urchin and vice versa. These experiments will directly determine whether there has been an evolutionary change in gene function and how any such changes alter development. This project will provide a highly mechanistic understanding of how evolutionary changes in gene function can lead to the development of novel structures and will provide intensive research experiences for several undergraduates and a woman graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long term goal of this project is to understand how evolutionary processes operating in the genome lead to the evolution of animal development.  We use early embryos of three species of echinoderms; sea urchin, sea star and sea cucumber, to understand these processes, as each group has specific differences in the development of particular cell type, the larval skeleton.  The sea urchin forms a complex skeleton, the sea cucumber forms only a small spicule while the sea star doesn’t form any skeleton. This project takes advantage of the extensive gene regulatory network (GRN) model that explains how the various cell types including the skeleton of the sea urchin are formed. GRNs are models that attempt to incorporate all genes that act within any particular developmental context and their regulatory interactions; most often between transcription factors and their regulatory DNA targets.  This project aims to understand how this regulatory network can change and this has broad implications for understanding development and evolution among all groups of animals.

We determined extensive GRNs for the sea star and compared these to sea urchin GRNs to understand how these networks evolve.  We showed that, although sea star embryos do not form a larval skeleton, both the sea urchin and sea star used a very similar GRN sub-circuit that uses positive feedback. This indicates that conserved circuitry may operate to establish specification of a broad cell type but does not limit the evolutionary capacity for change that operates in the downstream GRN. We also unexpectedly found the first empirical evidence of a transcriptional gradient of a molecule, beta catenin, being used in the formation of the primary axis of the sea star. This is mechanism widely used in vertebrate embryos and by now extending this to invertebrates, we hypothesize that such a dosage dependent response may represent a common and basal mode of development among animals. Ability to respond differently to the gradient may provide a mechanism to evolve changes in how early embryonic territories are established. We also showed that the early development of neurons use a modular GRN that separates patterning and specification. We hypothesize that this establishes a mechanism whereby patterning can evolve, in part, independently of the specification of neurons. Such GRN structure can account for the variation in neural patterning of this highly conserved cell types observed among these classes and among many groups of animals.

Finally, It is well established that GRNs can evolve extensively through mutations to regulatory DNA. Protein coding changes are considered to be rare, especially for genes encoding transcription factors as they are multifunctional and hence are more constrained to evolve in ways that will not produce widespread detrimental effects.  The Bulyk Lab (Harvard Med) developed new technologies to assess protein:DNA interactions that have unearthed a surprising variation in DNA binding abilities of transcription factors. My lab group was fascinated to understand whether this variation could exist for orthologous transcription factors and how this might contribute to GRN evolution of the larval skeleton. We therefore collaborated with the Bulky group on this problem. We demonstrated that these orthologous transcription factors have evolved a changed preference for a secondary binding motif. We showed that the primary and secondary motifs differed significantly in their affinities. This uncovers a layer of transcription factor binding divergence that could exist for many pairs of orthologs.  We hypothesize that this divergence provides modularity that allows orthologous transcription factors to evolve novel roles in GRNs through modification of binding to secondary sites.
